Title X vs. Trump administration Let ' s start with some background .

In response to the Trump administration ' s action , U.S. Rep Mark Pocan , D-Madison , sent out this tweet : " In WI , over 79 % of Title X patients rely on Planned Parenthood for their basic health care . "
To be sure , Planned Parenthood does provide more general health care .
Title X is a federal grant program that serves low-income patients or those who don ' t have health insurance .
Of that group , 1.6 million are served by Planned Parenthood centers .
The program distributes about $ 260 million a year in family planning grants .

According to the Guttmacher Institute , a research organization operating out of Washington D.C. and New York City that studies and advocates for the advancement of sexual and reproductive health and rights , Title X-funded providers serve about 3.8 million contraceptive clients .
The program helps provide patients with cancer screenings , STD testing and annual exams for women , but it does not fund abortion care .
It was first enacted in 1970 and signed into law by President Richard Nixon .

Instead of complying with the new rules , Planned Parenthood decided to pull out of the federal program , saying that forcing Title X providers to stop referring abortions would be unfair to patients and limit their access to reproductive health options .

label: NOT ENOUGH INFO
claim: Wages are on the rise - in fact we were the top small-business wage growth state in the nation.
evidences: Illinois comes in at 3.84 % , just .01 % better than Missouri .

By the numbers A spokesperson for Parson ' s campaign cited an April 2019 article from St. Louis Business Journal that used numbers from an April 2019 report from Paychex/IHS Market Small Business Employment Watch to show Missouri ranked first in the country in hourly wage growth for small businesses .

According to the Small Business Employment Watch ' s September report , Missouri now ranks third in the country in hourly wage growth increase at 3.38 % ( New York is second at 3.53 % and Illinois is first at 4.11 % ) .
If assessing for weekly wage growth rise , Missouri is second at 3.83 % .
At $ 25.55 per hour , Missouri small business wages were up 3.48 % , or 86 cents , that month .
" With record lows in unemployment , more people are going back to work in Missouri , " Parson said Sept. 8 .
We wanted to investigate .
The Show-Me State finished first ahead of California , New York , Arizona and Illinois in small-business wage growth .
According to a Paychex spokesperson , the sample includes millions of small-business workers .
So what is Paychex , and how does it calculate its data for the Small Business Employment Watch ?
Does the governor ' s comment check out ?
It depends what you consider a small business .
All businesses whose wage data is included in the report must have run payroll for the month that the data is being compiled and the three months prior .
During his recent election announcement for governor of Missouri , Mike Parson trumpeted a strong economy in the state , taking particular care to highlight increases in small-business wages .
Paychex defines a small business as a firm with fewer than 50 workers , but the U.S. Small Business Administration defines small businesses as firms with less than 500 workers .
Overall , Missouri has been a top-five small business wage growth state ( by weekly earnings ) every month this year , according to Paychex ' s analysis .
The company itself claims to work with one in 12 private sector employees .
" Wages are on the rise - in fact we were the top small-business wage growth state in the nation . "
How many small-business workers are there in Missouri and in the United States ?

claim: " Says drinking cream of tartar mixed with orange juice daily will help people quit smoking because it ""flushes the nicotine"" out of the body."
evidences: There is no scientific evidence to support the claim that drinking cream of tartar and orange juice rids the body of nicotine and thus helps people quit smoking .
The Cream of Tartar flushes the nicotine out of your system and blocks it from receiving it again !
The post features a picture of cream of tartar with a lengthy caption that says : " Go to your favorite grocery store and buy Cream of Tartar Seasoning and a gallon of Orange Juice .
( Read more about our partnership with Facebook . )
Quitting smoking is hard .
While potassium-rich cream of tartar has a diuretic effect , meaning it increases urine production , this doesn ' t explain how it would somehow impact metabolism .

The Shareably article alleges that the way cream of tartar helps " flush " nicotine out of the body is by getting " your adrenal glands working in conjunction with the rest of your body ... Then your body naturally decides which toxins to eliminate through bowel movements , urine , and sweat . "
The list goes on .
And that ' s because it is .
According to a viral Facebook post that ' s been shared over 300,000 times since Oct. 14 , simply mixing cream of tartar powder with orange juice will " flush the nicotine out of your system . "
The basis behind the claim is problematic because it relies on unsupported theories about detoxifying the body through various diets or cleanses .
But it is unclear how that could even work .
Mix 1 teaspoon in a glass and drink once a day .
After about two days , smoking tastes like s*** , you 're blocked from the nicotine rush and the desire is gone ! "
Over the years , ex-smokers have sworn by a myriad of methods : pills , patches , cold turkey .
I recommend when you get up and another glass halfway through your day .
But one cheap and easy quit-smoking-fast tactic making the rounds on Facebook sounds too easy to be true .
The post was flagged as part of Facebook ' s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed .

label: REFUTES
claim: Ohio, Michigan, and Pennsylvania actually in the latest jobs data have lost jobs, not gained them.
evidences: The latest official release state-by-state employment trends is current through August 2019 .
Michigan : A gain of 6,100 jobs Pennsylvania : A gain of 16,500 jobs .
Here ' s what you get if you compare the August 2019 figures to the July 2019 figures : Ohio : A gain of 3,700 jobs .
Each state has seen its employment levels rise .
During the Democratic debate in Westerville , Ohio , Julian Castro took a shot at President Donald Trump ' s stewardship of the economy - especially in three key Midwestern states Trump won in 2016 .
So how does Castro support his claim of job losses in those states ?
More to the point , Castro didn ' t provide any indication in his statement that he was using a non-standard comparison .

The August numbers will indeed be revised - here ' s a primer on employment data revisions we put together recently - but it ' s not a common practice to simply wave away the most recent figures because they will eventually be revised .
Here ' s what we found when we looked at the official Bureau of Labor Statistics numbers in the simplest , most traditional fashion .
And here are the employment trends since Trump took office in 2016 , using BLS data collected by the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis .
Castro ' s campaign got back to us with an explanation , but it relies on an atypical reading of the numbers to achieve its effect .
All employment numbers are eventually revised , yet economists regularly study the most recent ones , politicians talk about them , and the media covers them .

" All of us are out there every single day talking about what we 're going to do to make sure that more people cross a graduation stage , that more families have great health care , that more folks are put to work in places like Ohio , where Donald Trump has broken his promises , " Castro said , " because Ohio , Michigan , and Pennsylvania actually in the latest jobs data have lost jobs , not gained them . "
He argued that July is a better measurement because the August numbers will be revised before being made official .

label: REFUTES
claim: Ohio, Michigan, and Pennsylvania actually in the latest jobs data have lost jobs, not gained them.
evidences: His campaign told PolitiFact that he compared March figures with July figures , showing that employment dropped in Ohio by 7,300 , in Michigan by 11,500 , and in Pennsylvania by 4,500 .
For instance , here ' s the change for the full-year period between August 2018 and August 2019 : Ohio : A gain of 24,800 jobs .
Michigan : A gain of 16,000 jobs Pennsylvania : A gain of 38,400 jobs .

What his figures amount to are a cherry-picked month-to-month quirk that paints a misleading picture of the job trends in each of these states .

claim: "Traditionally, the Speaker says: 'Members of Congress, I have the high privilege and distinct honor of presenting to you the President of the United States.' (Tonight) Speaker Pelosi said, 'Members of Congress, the President of the United States.' """
evidences: Tapper wrote , " Traditionally , the Speaker says : ' Members of Congress , I have the high privilege and distinct honor of presenting to you the President of the United States. In 2020 , Pelosi did say part of the phrase - but as Tapper noted , it was just a part .
She said : " Members of Congress , the president of the United States . "
2008 : Pelosi to Bush : " Members of Congress , I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States . "
It ' s unclear whether there was a miscommunication , but Pelosi insisted to reporters later that " there was no snub .
In 2019 , Pelosi didn ' t say anything before Trump started speaking .
We looked back at all of the speaker-president interactions in State of the Union addresses going back to 2007 , which was Pelosi ' s first as speaker .
CNN host Jake Tapper noted the shift in his post-speech analysis , as well as in a tweet that attracted more than 36,000 likes .
Pelosi ' s office did not respond to an inquiry for this article .
2018 : Ryan to Trump : " Members of Congress , I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States . "

Between the 2007 and 2018 addresses , every speaker has said something very close to the following : " Members of Congress , I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States . "
2010 : Pelosi to Obama : " Members of Congress , I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States . "

2007 : Pelosi to President George W. Bush : " Members of Congress , I have the high privilege and the distinct honor of presenting to you the president of the United States . "

It went quickly , I guess . "

Specifically , the number of trash-and-recyclable-filled bags per volunteer dropped from an average of 2.14 bags in 2007 to 1.20 in 2019 .
In an interview with the Atlantic , Carlson said he ' s been fishing in the river , which stretches from West Virginia into the Chesapeake Bay , for almost 35 years .
When they hit the water , they harm wildlife , degrade habitats and taint the water , making it less clean and safe .
Litter isn ' t the main problem Local experts also cast doubt on Carlson ' s claim that immigrant litter was at fault .
Litter is still an issue .
" I go down there , and that litter is left almost exclusively by immigrants . "
And in a dense city like Washington , there ' s likely more litter to go around than elsewhere .
But that litter " is really a problem that spans society , " Dalpra said .

label: REFUTES
claim: " Delaware has the ""eighth-largest black population in the country"""
evidences: " There are more black people in one county in Florida than in Delaware , " said Keneshia Grant , a Howard University political scientist who does research on black voters .
Delaware has about 220,000 black residents , placing it around the bottom one-third of states .
" It looks like the ten cities with the largest black populations all have larger black populations than the entire state of Delaware . "
Former Vice President Joe Biden exaggerated the size of the black population in Delaware in an interview in which he spoke about why he thinks he has more black support than Mayor Pete Buttigieg .
( Biden has been making similar statements at least since 2006 . )

The percentage of black residents in Delaware is significant in terms of showing that Biden had to take into account the concerns of black voters when he was a senator there , University of Delaware political scientist David Redlawsk said .
The top states in order were Mississippi , Louisiana , Georgia , Maryland , Alabama , South Carolina , Delaware and North Carolina .
Biden was referring to a comparison of the black population in states and Washington , D.C. by percentage , but he didn ' t mention the word " percentage " in that interview .
By population , the top five states would be Texas , Georgia , Florida , New York and California .
We found that in some interviews Biden states that he is talking about a percentage while in other instances he omits that crucial explanation .
William Frey , a demographer at the Brookings Institution who is known for his research on race , said it is appropriate to look at the percent of the black population for the state .
But it ' s important to understand how small the Delaware population is .
A Census spokesman told us that both metrics - the percentage and raw numbers - are useful data , but it provides a more complete picture to look at both of them .
" This is best expressed in terms of a percentage , which provides the relative importance to his own elections , " he said .
If we include the District of Columbia , then Delaware would be in eighth place .
In Biden ' s case , he was using the statistic to make his case that he has a history of representing black voters and cares about issues of importance to them .
However , Frey said , Biden ' s comment would be more compelling if applied to a state with a large black percentage and sheer numbers such as Georgia .
Delaware was in seventh place - about 22.5 % of the population is black .
In terms of raw numbers , Delaware - a state with a population of just under 1 million - has a small black population that does not rank among the top states .

RELATED : U.S. minorities surpassed 25 % of electorate when Obama ran in 2008 , and it 's going up What Census data shows for Delaware ' s black population The U.S. Census sent us 2018 data showing the percent of the African American population in each state .
But if we look at raw numbers , Delaware does not rank among the top states for the size of the black population .
" I come out of an environment where I have the eighth-largest black population in the country , in my state , and that 's where I got my political education , " he told Axios .

label: SUPPORTS
claim: " Real wages ""went up last year 1.1%."""
evidences: According to the latest U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics numbers , Sanders is correct .
The agency reported that real average hourly earnings were 1.1 % higher in November compared with 2018 .
See Figure 1 on PolitiFact.com After the Great Recession , real wages began to grow again in 2014 .
There are other ways to track wage trends .
When people talk about real earnings , they mean how much workers make after taking the cost of living into account .
In 2018 , wages rose fastest for those at the bottom end of the pay scale .
That ai n't great . "
Broadly , the rise is consistent with the long-running economic growth the country has seen .
The trends , however , will vary depending on the sort of workers ( all workers , or just production and nonsupervisory ones ) and the time period .
There ' s no way to quantify whether a 1.1 % increase " ain ' t great , " as Sanders said .
" You know what real inflation accounted-for wages went up last year ?
The highest jump was 2.2 % in 2015 .
For real median weekly wages for all full-time workers , the rise was 1.3 % over the course of the year , again using government data .
There is an encouraging sign for lower wage workers .
It is not the biggest increase workers have seen in recent years .
In the Democratic debate in Los Angeles , Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders pushed back against the idea that President Donald Trump can point to a strong economy as he runs for re-election .
" Trump goes around saying the economy is doing great , " Sanders said Dec. 19 .
In general , for the production and nonsupervisory group , real weekly earnings have been rising since the late 1990s , with significant dips during recessions .
In that light , 1.1 % is better than average .
But looking back to 1980 , the average yearly change is .3 % .
When costs rise , it eats away at the increase people see in their paychecks .
With wages , there are many possible ways to slice the data , and no single measure captures the full story .

label: REFUTES

evidences: As well , a reverse-image search shows versions of the photo on the internet as early as 2008 –– four years before Stevens ' death .

The video shows what looks like a light-colored helicopter spinning out of control against a brownish , mountainous background before it crashes and bursts into flames and billowing black smoke .

The headline of the article , which blasts Siemon as being " on a mission to empty her community ' s local prison , " suggests that the prosecutor wants to free the 90 killers and is moving to do so .
But the article ' s headline goes further , suggesting that the prosecutor is seeking the release of 90 inmates .
But the article itself says only that Siemon will begin a review of the 90 cases .

City Pulse reported : " Siemon - with pro-bono help from former Assistant Attorney General Ron Emery - this year plans to begin a formal review of the 90 convicted murderers serving life in prison without parole in Ingham County .

" I regret that I did not fully take into account the impact on victims and their families when I prematurely discussed the concept of reviewing older cases of life-without-parole , " Siemon said .

As it happens , this statistic had already caused some controversy in West Virginia by the time Manchin wrote his post .

evidences: Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security on Oct. 16 , 2019 , tweeted a picture of the stuffed microbe as part of its Event 201 registration drive : " Have you registered for the # Event201 virtual pandemic exercise yet ? "

Two months before the outbreak of Novel Coronavirus ( 2019-nCoV ) was detected in Wuhan , China , the Event 201 scenario - which was organized by John Hopkins Center for Health Security World Economic Forum and Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation - " simulated a novel zoonotic coronavirus transmitted from bats to pigs to people that eventually becomes efficiently transmissible from person to person , leading to a severe pandemic , " according to the Event 201 website .

The fictionalized scenario , which was planned in part because there have been two worldwide outbreaks of coronaviruses in the last 20 years , also included 65 million related deaths in 18 months from the pretend coronavirus .

Also among the requesters categorized as " firms " were the National Consumer Law Center , a non-profit that focuses on legal and policy work for low income citizens ; the Public Rights Project , an organization that advances civil rights and economic justice policies ; and Judicial Watch , another right-leaning non-profit focused on government transparency .

Is his comparison accurate ?

Unlike the United States , which has a lot of economically competitive natural gas under development , China doesn ' t , said Anna Mikulska , a nonresident fellow in energy studies at the Center for Energy Studies at Rice University 's Baker Institute for Public Policy .
That said , the Paris-based International Energy Agency , has projected that China ' s coal consumption will indeed decline over the next two decades .
" How does it make sense that in China , they ' re burning seven to eight times the amount of coal that we ' re burning in the United States ? "
Justice is arguing that greenhouse gases do not stay within national borders ; they spread everywhere in the atmosphere .
The project Justice criticized aspires to retire all coal use by 2030 while securing an economic future for fossil fuel-producing communities .
However , adjusting for population is less significant in this case than it often is , given Justice ' s point .
" This is why we see China still consuming so much . "
The new initiative would build on this effort and also " work to stop the construction of new gas plants , " Bloomberg wrote .
In addition , the same data shows that China ' s coal consumption increased by 1.8 % between 2007 and 2017 , whereas U.S. coal consumption declined by 4.9 % .
At one point in the press conference , Justice was asked about the environmental impacts of fossil fuels .
What about population ?
" By the time they are built , they will be out of date because renewable energy will be cheaper . "
So any decreases in carbon emissions made in the United States will be a relatively small factor compared to China in the global context - regardless of which country has a bigger population .
Justice didn ' t mention it , but another country , India , also consumes more coal than the United States does - 452 million tons of oil equivalent , according to the BP review .
Indeed , according to the BP data , China accounted for just over half of the world ' s coal consumption in 2018 .
Justice , a Republican whose state is a leading producer of coal and other carbon-based energy , said the effort could be " catastrophic " to West Virginia .
He responded by questioning the value of the United States cutting back if China is using carbon-based fuels on full blast .

label: REFUTES
claim: Video shows Gianna Bryant in the hospital after helicopter crash.
evidences: The Pacific Attorney Group reported that Cervantes was one of two people killed by a traffic collision on Aug. 28 , 2019 , in Downey , Calif. She died two days later in the hospital .

The video description says that Cervantes was an organ donor who received an honor walk , a ritual described by the New York Times as a way to show respect to dying patients planning to donate their organs .
The original video was titled " Ariana ' s Honor Walk " and was uploaded to YouTube on Sept. 4 , 2019 .
A video claims to show Gianna Bryant being ushered through a hospital , surrounded by medical staff .
The post was flagged as part of Facebook ' s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed .
While this video does feature a young woman who was killed in an accident , that woman is 28-year-old Ariana Cervantes .
Bryant died with her father Kobe Bryant in a helicopter crash on Jan. 26 .
As of Jan. 28 , the video has 485,771 views on YouTube and 112,600 likes on the original TikTok it appeared in .
( Read more about our partnership with Facebook . )
But that didn ' t happen .
The full version of this video was uploaded more than four months before Gianna Bryant ' s death .
She is slowly moved down a hallway lined with doctors and nurses in the first part of the video , and in the second she is surrounded by hospital staff and mourners .
The video shows a young girl laying motionless on a hospital bed .
The next day , a video titled , " Kobe Bryant Daughter Gianna Bryant Final Hours " was uploaded to YouTube .
Together , they ' ve been shared thousands of times .

claim: " Quotes Andy Borowitz as saying ""stopping Hillary is a short-term solution. The long-term solution - and it will be more difficult - is fixing the educational system that has created so many people ignorant enough to vote for Hillary."""
evidences: The quote in the image is doctored to make it look like Borowitz is being critical of Clinton .
To be fair , he said most of it , but with one rather significant difference : He was talking about then-presidential candidate Donald Trump , not Clinton .
The only words altered in the Facebook post ' s version are the two references to " Hillary , " in which Borowitz actually wrote " Trump . "
We found that he posted the statement on his verified Facebook page on Nov. 4 , 2016 , four days before the presidential election .
While that particular post was deleted while we were fact-checking it , we found the image several other places .
( Read more about our partnership with Facebook . )
Andy Borowitz is a writer and comedian who authors the popular satirical column " The Borowitz Report " for the New Yorker .
The post that we found had been shared on Facebook more than 3,000 times and featured a photograph of Borowitz alongside text that reads : " Stopping Hillary is a short-term solution .
But we recently came across a statement falsely attributed to Borowitz on social media that disparages Hillary Clinton and people who voted for her .
The long-term solution –– and it will be more difficult –– is fixing the educational system that has created so many people ignorant enough to vote for Hillary . "

A wild tale about a horse thief ancestor of former Democratic Sen. Harry Reid continues to spread online despite being debunked for several years The online story has been circulating since at least 2000 , targeting not only Reid but several political figures .
Other versions have featured the surnames of President Donald Trump , former President George W. Bush , Hillary Clinton and Al Gore , among others .

The post claims a genealogy researcher named Judy Wallman was working on her family tree when she found that the former senator from Nevada has a great-great uncle , Remus Reid , who was " hanged for horse stealing and train robbery in Montana in 1889 , " and whom Wallman also shared as an ancestor .
The post was flagged as part of Facebook ' s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed .

label: REFUTES
claim: Today in America - a new study came out - 20 years out, whites who borrowed money, 94% of them have paid off their student loan debt; 5% of African Americans have paid it off.
evidences: Warren claimed the study said that only 5 % of African American borrowers had paid off their student debt .
Warren claimed that the study said that 20 years out , 94 % of white borrowers had paid off their student loans .
The problem here is that Warren talked about borrowers , whereas the statistic she tried to cite from the study talked about the amounts borrowed .
But the study found that the median debt of black borrowers had decreased by only 5 % .
But what the study ' s measure of student debt actually found is that , 20 years after starting college , the median debt of white borrowers had been reduced by 94 % .

Study Warren cites The major finding of the Brandeis study is this : " Twenty years after starting college , the median debt of white borrowing students has been reduced by 94 % - with almost half holding no student debt - whereas black borrowers at the median still owe 95 % of their cumulative borrowing total . "
In the Nov. 20 Democratic presidential debate , Sen. Elizabeth Warren called for student loan debt forgiveness after citing a startling racial disparity statistic .
Student loan debt totals nearly $ 1.5 trillion , according to an August 2019 report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York .
But Warren misstated these two figures .
It is a result of increases in both the number of borrowers and the loan balances they carry .
That ' s as high as it ' s ever been and up about 200 % from 2006 , we ' ve found .
Student debt at record high Warren has proposed that , for anyone making under $ 100,000 , the federal government would pay off up to $ 50,000 of their debt .
" In the important discourse concerning student debt and when race is added , Sen. Warren is right on the mark , " said Tom Shapiro , director of Brandeis ' Institute on Assets and Social Policy .

Three student debt experts who were not part of the study pointed out another racial disparity finding of the study : 48 % of white borrowers had paid off their student loans , compared with 26 % of black borrowers .
One of the study ' s authors told us that Warren gets right the broader policy point that there are racial disparities in student debt that should be addressed .
But , as we ' ve laid out , the way she stated it in the debate was wrong .
The government would also help people making up to $ 250,000 , although on a sliding scale .
There are racial disparities when it comes to student debt .

A Warren campaign spokesman acknowledged that Warren misquoted the study , saying the study is " another alarming reminder of why we need to cancel student loan debt and close the racial wealth gap . "

" Today in America - a new study came out - 20 years out , whites who borrowed money , 94 % of them have paid off their student loan debt ; 5 % of African Americans have paid it off , " Warren , D-Mass. , said .

As for race , 17.7 % of borrowers who live in black-majority ZIP codes default on their student loans - nearly double the rate ( 9 % ) of borrowers from white-majority areas , according to a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York released a week before the debate .
We wondered about data for the borrowers .
But Warren ' s claim alludes to a September 2019 report from Brandeis University in Massachusetts .

But he ' s applying the practice of replacing political appointees - and wrongly characterizing what Obama did , to a large extent - to career diplomats .

She is a career diplomat , not a political appointee , who has served under three presidents .

The president ' s supporters have tried to discredit Yovanovitch - and the entire probe , for that matter .
Also , she was ousted more than two years into Trump ' s presidency , not during a transition period .

The breaking news format of this social media claim came from a website that allows you to create your own breaking news stories by uploading your own image and headline into a generator .
The Novel Coronavirus has been surrounded by panic and misinformation since its discovery in December 2019 .
The most recent false claim is that cocaine is the cure .
We wouldn ' t recommend trying a highly addictive drug in hopes of fighting off a viral disease .
( Read more about our partnership with Facebook . )
This image is made by an online news generator .

One Facebook post from Jan. 30 included an image of a bag of cocaine in the background of a news banner that says " Cocaine kills corona virus " and " Scientists is shocked to discover that this drug can fight the virus . "
There have been 1,016 deaths reported worldwide from the coronavirus as of Feb. 10 , none in the United States .
In 2017 there were a total of 13,942 drug overdose deaths in the United States that involved cocaine .
This post was flagged by Facebook as part of efforts to combat false news and information on its News Feed .
Images of breaking news stories claiming that cocaine is the newest remedy to coronavirus are being reposted on Twitter and Facebook .
No , this grammatically challenged image was not from a real breaking news alert .
There is still no cure for the coronavirus .
In the original image of the bag of cocaine , which can be found on multiple stock image sites , there was no blurry white spot in the corner .
If there were a cure for the Novel Coronavirus , we wouldn ' t count on it being a stimulant like cocaine .
Cocaine is a highly addictive drug that can lead to long-term respiratory problems and movement disorders like Parkinson ' s disease , according to the National Institutes of Health .

label: REFUTES
claim: President Trump has sent 14,000 American troops to the (Middle East) region since May. So he can't tell his political rallies that he's getting troops out of endless wars when he's sending 14 times the amount back into the region.
evidences: So yes , Trump has sent 14 times as many soldiers to the Middle East as the approximately 1,000 troops that he pledged to remove when he announced his decision to pull out of Syria .

The latest on Syria , American troops McGurk said he got his numbers from the Pentagon , which touted its troop commitments in an Oct. 11 press release announcing the deployment of about 3,000 U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia .
The press release said the Pentagon had " increased the number of forces by approximately 14,000 to the U.S. Central Command area of responsibility " since May .
According to the Royal Institute of International Affairs , a London think tank , they do not include temporary forces or classified special forces operating in secret .
Brett McGurk , Trump ' s former special envoy for the coalition to counter the Islamic State , said leaving Syria opens the door for Russian and Iranian aggression in the Middle East .
The Pentagon has said it will shift about 1,000 American troops from Syria to western Iraq .
Those numbers include active duty personnel , national guard and reserve personnel and civilian personnel .

The Pentagon told us it would not identify the recently deployed personnel by country , but it said more than 6,500 of the 14,000 soldiers sent out since May are at sea as part of the Abraham Lincoln Carrier Strike Group .
Experts told us it ' s difficult to determine how U.S. forces are distributed in the Middle East , in part because of changes former Defense Secretary James Mattis made to reduce transparency .
Defense Secretary Mark Esper repeated the same figures while briefing reporters that same day .

" Trump is using the rhetoric of ending endless war , but in reality he is waging more war , " said Trita Parsi , co-founder and executive vice president of the Quincy Institute for Responsible Statecraft , a foreign policy think tank .
But relocation is not departure . "
But Todman said the recent reduction of U.S. troops in Afghanistan likely means more have been deployed to the Middle East anyway .
Troops began withdrawing to Iraq on Oct. 21 , per the Wall Street Journal .
But one critic of the move says Trump is breaking his own promise by sending troops back into other parts of the Middle East .
President Donald Trump has insisted that his decision to withdraw U.S. troops from the Syrian border with Turkey is a step toward getting the United States out of " endless " wars .

The Pentagon told us the term " area of responsibility " refers to " the entire Middle East , " while Will Todman , an associate fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies , said it also includes Afghanistan and other parts of central Asia .

According to June data from the Pentagon - which omits numbers for countries with ongoing operations such as Syria , Iraq and Afghanistan - there were at that time 283 total U.S. forces in Egypt , 76 in Israel , 20 in Lebanon , 1,750 in Turkey , 84 in Jordan , 2,077 in Kuwait , 535 in Saudi Arabia , 19 in Yemen , 17 in Oman , 374 in the United Arab Emirates , 636 in Qatar , and 4,865 in Bahrain .
Still , experts told us the largest numbers of U.S. forces currently stationed in or near the Middle East are likely in Bahrain , Iraq , Saudi Arabia , Kuwait , Qatar and Afghanistan .
( Definitions of the Middle East vary . )
Spoiler : McGurk ' s claim is spot-on .
We wanted to check if McGurk , who also served under Presidents George W. Bush and Barack Obama , was right that Trump has shipped 14,000 troops to the Middle East since May .
On Oct. 19 , Esper said the soldiers in northeast Syria would be relocated to western Iraq where they would " help defend Iraq " and fight against ISIS .
" In the Middle East , he is simply moving troops from one region to another .
More recently , Esper said the United States was considering leaving some troops behind to secure the region ' s oil fields , according to the Associated Press .
The June numbers are also outdated .
" So he ca n't tell his political rallies that he 's getting troops out of endless wars when he 's sending 14 times the amount back into the region . "

" That is one reason we 're seeing so much increased tension in the region and that President Trump has sent 14,000 American troops to the region since May , " McGurk told MSNBC anchor Chuck Todd on " Meet the Press " Oct. 20 .

" Nothing in either the Constitution or House rules requires public hearings and/or cross-examination at this stage , " said Ilya Somin , professor of law at George Mason University .
If such rights apply at all , they would be granted during the Senate ' s trial phase .
By contrast , those three committees feature 13 , 23 and 26 Democrats , respectively , with four Democrats sitting on two of them at the same time .

Republicans also have the ability to ask questions of witnesses at hearings , Sherry said , which is " more opportunity for cross-examination than is given to a target of a grand jury investigation . "
" The House impeachment inquiry is equivalent to a grand jury investigation in a criminal case , " said Suzanna Sherry , professor of law at Vanderbilt University .

In three previous impeachments , the full House authorized inquiries and the House Judiciary Committee took the lead in conducting investigations , holding hearings and voting on whether to approve articles of impeachment .

" The thing that , of course , is top-drawer today and has been all week is what little Adam pencil-neck Schiff is doing behind closed doors in a so-called impeachment inquiry that doesn ' t feature the opposition party , it doesn ' t feature cross-examination , no transcripts are released , everything ' s being done in private , only selected leaks , you know the drill , " Limbaugh said Oct. 25 on his radio show .
This time around , Pelosi opened the inquiry without a formal vote , a move Republicans criticized .
Limbaugh , who did not respond to requests for comment , has a point that the impeachment hearings have so far taken place behind closed doors , without transcripts being formally released .
Conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh wrongly claimed that House Democrats leading the impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump are keeping Republicans out of their hearings .

Limbaugh ' s comments were made before House Speaker Nancy Pelosi ' s decision Oct. 28 to bring the probe to a more open phase , starting with an Oct. 31 vote on a resolution to affirm the ongoing investigation and start public hearings .

Kind - who was starting his second term in Congress at the time - was one of them .

At the time , Kind called the allegations " extremely serious " but said he wanted to gather all the facts before deciding whether impeachment was the proper path forward .
Kind has been less vocal on Trump and the impeachment process than his Democratic counterparts Gwen Moore of Milwaukee and Mark Pocan of Madison .
Is that true ?
Party lines aside , Kind says he has a one-of-a-kind distinction in Congress .

But the effort did not muster enough votes from the Senate to remove Clinton from office .
Let ' s fast forward to today .
The perjury charge passed the House with a 228-206 vote , while the charge for obstruction of justice passed with a 221-212 vote .
The Senate followed with a 50-50 split on the accusation that Clinton obstructed justice , but dismissed the charge of perjury 55-45 .
The case against Trump In October 2019 , House Democrats voted 232-196 - a vote that fell largely on party lines - to pursue an impeachment inquiry into Trump .
Kind voted against all of the articles of impeachment , and the House eventually voted to impeach on obstruction of justice and a single perjury charge .
Kind represents a district covering the western part of the state that Trump won by 4 percentage points in 2016 over Democrat Hillary Clinton .
Clinton ' s impeachment It ' s been more than 20 years since Clinton became the second president to be impeached .
The first was Andrew Johnson in 1868 .

The investigation revolves around accusations that Trump withheld military aid to Ukraine unless the country agreed to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden , a chief Trump rival in the 2020 presidential race .
" I am the only member of Congress that voted for both inquiries , the Clinton inquiry and now the Trump inquiry , " Kind said on WISN-TV ' s " UpFront " program .

Partisan politics in Washington has changed dramatically in the two decades between the votes , with today ' s open warfare fueled by a divide among the public that plays out every day on TV and social media .

After a nearly five-year investigation led by independent prosecutor Ken Starr , Clinton was ultimately impeached by the Republican-led U.S. House of Representatives on charges of perjury and obstruction of justice .
Ultimately , four articles of impeachment were brought against Clinton , including two perjury charges , one charge of abuse of power and one of obstruction of justice .

Kind has been open about his support for investigating Trump , but told Wisconsin Public Radio in an interview that aired Oct. 17 , 2019 that impeachment and removal from office should be a " last resort . "
He also referred to the actions involved in the allegation as unlawful , unpatriotic and unconstitutional .
In 1998 , the Wisconsin Democrat had to vote on an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton , a Democrat .

label: REFUTES
claim: Says the names of CNN anchors Chris Cuomo, Brian Stelter and Jake Tapper were on the flight logs of Jeffrey Epstein's private plane.
evidences: None of their names or initials are on the released Epstein flight logs .

The logs can be found online in a few places , and while there are certainly some noteworthy names , such as President Bill Clinton ( who issued a statement about the plane rides shortly after Epstein ' s arrest ) , the CNN anchors ' names are not on there .
The flight logs , which became public through civil lawsuits by women who said they were sexually abused by Epstein , span from 1997 to 2005 and were handwritten by pilot David Rodgers .
It was posted by the page " Q Army , " one of many social media pages related to the Q ' Anon conspiracy theory .

Other fake lists of alleged Lolita Express passengers can be found online and have included President Barack Obama , former Vice President Joe Biden , former U.S. Sen. Hillary Clinton , the late U.S. Sen. John McCain , Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and even Pope Francis , to name a few .
( Read more about our partnership with Facebook . )

One problematic Facebook post shares a photoshopped image of CNN anchors Chris Cuomo , Brian Stelter and Jake Tapper , and claims the three men ' s names are on the released flight logs of the Lolita Express .
But some have used the occasion to drum up false rumors about public figures , including placing them on Epstein ' s private Boeing 727 .

By the account of one woman who spoke to The Miami Herald and who filed a civil suit against Epstein that was settled in 2017 , the jet transported young women to entertain guests and was nicknamed " The Lolita Express , " which she described as " the vessel for him to abuse girls and get away with it . "
This rumor is fabricated .
After federal prosecutors lodged child sex trafficking charges against wealthy financier Jeffrey Epstein in early July , stories about those in his high-powered social circle took on new life .
The post ' s text reads : " Hey , CNN ... why are three of your anchor ' s names on the Epstein ' Lolita Express ' flight logs ? "
CNN spokesperson Barbara Levin told PolitiFact that there is " ZERO truth " to this rumor .
The post was flagged as part of Facebook ' s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed .

It added words she didn ' t say , such as " illegal immigrants not being able to see their kids . "
Here ' s what Warren actually said .
The 2018 murder of Mollie Tibbetts , a University of Iowa student , and the subsequent arrest of an undocumented immigrant became a flashpoint in the immigration debate .

Warren contrasted enforcement that targets those who have or might commit violence , and enforcement that separates small children from their parents - the " zero tolerance " policy under the Trump administration in 2018 .

label: REFUTES
claim: " Says voter roll purge would mean ""more than 200,000 registered Wisconsin voters will be prohibited from voting."""
evidences: The background The controversy began in October 2019 when the Wisconsin Elections Commission sent letters to 234,000 voters it believed may have moved because of information it received from the post office , Division of Motor Vehicles or other government entities .
The letters asked recipients to re-register at their new address if they had moved or to confirm they were still at their same address if they had n't .
Wisconsin election officials believe those people may have moved , so they sent letters inquiring about their status in October .

Related : Here 's what Wisconsin voters should do to ensure they 're registered properly All of this is a big deal in Wisconsin , a state President Donald Trump won by less than 23,000 votes in 2016 , a key factor in his victory .

Up to 234,000 Wisconsin residents are at risk of being removed from the voter rolls , a political lightning-rod that has drawn national attention given the state ' s critical role in the 2020 presidential election .
A Twitter account described as Pelosi ' s " political account " retweeted a statement from Wisconsin Democratic Party Chair Ben Wikler and then offered its own take on the situation .
The tweet does not appear to have been sent by Pelosi herself , since it was not signed with her initials , a style referenced in the account description .
" It ' s beyond alarming that more than 200,000 registered Wisconsin voters will be prohibited from voting , " the tweet said .

Officials have refused to release the names of those who received the letters , but a Milwaukee Journal Sentinel analysis of the mailings showed 55 % went to municipalities won by Democrat Hillary Clinton in 2016 .
That ' s 7 % of the 3.3 million registered voters in the state .
Here ' s why .
A higher percentage of voters received the mailings in traditional Democratic strongholds , such as Milwaukee , Madison and many college towns .
A series of ensuing lawsuits and court actions have sought to more quickly remove these people from the voting rolls - or delay that from happening .
There ' s clearly room for disagreement over how to handle the 234,000 voters .
But Pelosi ' s claim is a significant exaggeration of what ' s at stake .
The controversy caught the attention of U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi , a Democrat .

Ayan Ahmed is a spokesperson with the Polaris Project , a nonprofit organization that works to combat and prevent modern-day slavery and human trafficking .

She provided PolitiFact with a statement from the organization that read that most human traffickers lure victims using psychological means such as tricking , defrauding , manipulating or threatening .

The posts – like this one – claim that sex traffickers are leaving zip ties on cars ( and sometimes mailboxes and fences ) to either mark targets or to distract and kidnap women when they try to remove the ties .
Polaris encourages people to educate themselves and others about the realities of human trafficking .
But we did not locate any legitimate mentions of the zip ties being used as a way to target or distract people .
Viral posts on Facebook are warning women to be wary if they find a zip tie attached to their vehicles .
Survivors often report being trafficked by people they know .

claim: " Says the Associated Press was wrong to report that ""Income Inequality grew to largest in 50 years"" because in a ""new Census report all four measures of income inequality SHRUNK, reversing rise over past five decades."""
evidences: In 2018 , the American Community Survey put the Gini Index at 0.485 , a statistically significant increase from 2017 , when the Gini Index was estimated to be 0.482 .

" The gap between the haves and have-nots in the United States grew last year to its highest level in more than 50 years of tracking income inequality , " the story reads , attributing the information to the Census Bureau .

News reports describe growing inequality Let ' s start with The Associated Press article , which was published upon the release of new income information from the U.S. Census Bureau ' s American Community Survey at the end of September .
The Current Population Survey report uses two different " income concepts " to measure inequality : money income and equivalence-adjusted income .
" However , they are also difficult to interpret , whereas the Gini has a more straightforward interpretation , " reads the statement from the Census Bureau .
Multiple news outlets wrote articles about the new data released by the Census Bureau , including The Washington Post .
Cooper of the Economic Policy Institute offered a similar assessment .

" Income inequality in the United States has hit its highest level since the Census Bureau started tracking it more than five decades ago , according to data released Thursday , even as the nation ' s poverty and unemployment rates are at historic lows , " the Post article reads .
The value for Gini can vary , depending on the survey and other factors .
The value ranges from 0 ( perfect equality , when everyone receives an equal share ) to 1 ( perfect inequality , when one group or recipient receives all the income ) .

While the Current Population Survey can show changes in income inequality over longer periods of time , " it is relatively rare for year-to-year changes in the Gini to be statistically significant , " due to the small sample size of the survey , according to the statement .
National Public Radio reported that the " gap between the richest and the poorest U.S. households is now the largest it ' s been in the past 50 years . "

" The most obvious thing going on is that they are talking about two different data sources , " said Rakesh Kochhar , a senior researcher at the Pew Research Center who studies trends in income and wealth .
Money income is household income , while equivalence-adjusted income considers the number of people in a household and how they might share resources .

Kochhar said the Current Population Survey should be " understood as a national survey , " while the American Community Survey " is designed for measurement across states , metro areas and counties . "

The Census Bureau and economics experts we consulted for this fact-check said it is normal to see variations in these measurements , depending on the source of the data and the income concept used for the estimate .
We had to ask : Who is right ?
Three of the measures , not including the Mean logarithmic deviation , saw a statistically significant decrease .

Gwozdz said when Brady referenced " four measures of income inequality , " he was looking at values for Gini , Theil , Atkinson and the Mean Logarithmic Deviation from the Current Population Survey report on 2018 Income and Poverty .
Plus , the Current Population Survey uses a smaller sample size .
It is a different project than the American Community Survey , which has a significantly larger sample size and collects information on population , housing and other topics - including income .
" Bottom line : The AP story is accurate , " Cooper said. "
Looking at equivalence-adjusted income , all four measures decreased from 2017 to 2018 .
Looking just at money income , all four summary measures appeared to show declining inequality from 2017 to 2018 .
" In new Census report all four measures of income inequality SHRUNK , reversing rise over past five decades . "
The article goes on to discuss a change to the Gini Index - a common summary measure of income inequality .
So , how is it possible that Brady came to a different conclusion about the status of income inequality in the U.S. after reviewing Census Bureau data ?

" The two surveys are different in methodology , sample size , and reporting period , so it ' s not unusual for them to report slightly different findings , " said David Cooper , a senior economic analyst at the Economic Policy Institute .
None of the statistics that Mr. Brady cites disprove anything that the AP story reports . "
In the Census Bureau ' s press release announcing the latest survey , the agency said income inequality in 2018 was " significantly higher " than in 2017 .

The Current Population Survey also uses the Gini Index , as well as three other summary measures of inequality - Theil , Atkinson and Mean Logarithmic Deviation - while the American Community Survey only includes Gini .
" The Gini coefficient is the most commonly used measure of inequality . "
A key difference between the surveys is that the Current Population Survey asks more detailed questions about income than the American Community Survey .
Is the United States experiencing the highest levels of income inequality in the past 50 years , or do the latest figures show a decline in inequality ?

U.S. Rep. Kevin Brady , a Texas Republican , tried his hand at fact-checking in a tweet that suggested a news report from The Associated Press inaccurately characterized the state of income inequality in the United States .

His post - which caught our attention due to his unauthorized use of a PolitiFact Truth-O-Meter image - started by summarizing the findings of the news article : " Income Inequality grew to largest in 50 years . "
Ken-Hou Lin , a sociology professor at the University of Texas at Austin , said that both The Associated Press and Brady should be more cautious with their interpretations of the Census Bureau data .
" FACT : Just the opposite , " Brady wrote .
